title: Every Second Counts – Identifying and Treating Acute Chest Syndrome

content: "How can I prevent my child from getting acute chest syndrome (ACS)? Have I overlooked something? How can I protect her?" These were just a few of the thousand questions I repeatedly asked the hematologist. Searching for hope and something to hold on to because I want to do everything in my power to ensure my little princess doesn't have to go through this again.
The conversations I’ve had over the past weeks have been the hardest ever. The feeling of helplessness and the uncertainty are terrible. I’m writing from the perspective of a mother and caregiver.

Looking back at what we have been through, there is one very important aspect I want to share. For me, it's crucial that caregivers and warriors recognize these things and act in time. Because by recognizing certain things, we were able to prevent worse.
Chest Pain, Difficulty Breathing, and a Fever

I noticed that my little princess was a bit warm and wanted to be sure she didn’t have a fever. So, I took her temperature, and it was 106! I thought my thermometer was broken, so I tried again. I grabbed another one to confirm. It fluctuated between 104 and 106. I immediately called the hospital because this was way too high. They allowed me to bring her to the clinic, and they gave her IV fluids, painkillers, and antibiotics. We arrived with chest pain, difficulty breathing, and a fever.

content: After a few hours, she was sent home, and we were told we would be called with the results of her blood culture and chest X-ray. They said the fever would go down on its own as the antibiotics started working.

In the evening, things didn’t get better, so I called the on-call hematologist because I was worried. They advised me to wait 3-5 days as the fever would drop once the antibiotics took effect. No need to panic, and she should rest well.
I didn’t trust it because the symptoms persisted: chest pain, difficulty breathing, fever. My little princess became quiet and just wanted to sleep.

sections.heading: Every Second Is Crucial
content: By chance, I had gone through a presentation on acute chest syndrome (ACS) a few weeks earlier related to a project I wanted to do with an international partner. The slide where they showed how quickly acute chest syndrome develops in the lungs stuck with me.

It showed the different time intervals for taking X-rays, where ACS isn’t visible at first, but within a few hours, a completely different picture appears. It keeps getting worse the more frequently you take X-rays. Mind you, when I saw this presentation, my daughter had never had ACS before. So this was very new and specific information for me.

content: Looking back, that presentation was a blessing! Thanks to those confrontational images, I became extremely concerned when the hematologist told me I could safely wait 3-5 days.

I knew that if she had ACS, every second was crucial. So I called a good friend of mine, who is a pediatrician, and explained what had happened and that I was very worried. The first thing he asked me was: What are you still doing at home?
You need to go to the ER with her immediately and get a new X-ray because this is ACS.

We went straight to the ER (at a different hospital, of course), and sure enough! The X-ray didn’t look good, and our worst fears were confirmed. We were transferred by ambulance from the ER to the children’s hospital.

The hospital acted very quickly. My little princess was admitted immediately. The treatment began, and my daughter fought hard for her life. I could write an entire book about this one experience, but for now, I’d like to share the lessons learned so that you can recognize this in time and ensure that the right steps are taken to protect the life of your loved one. Every second counts with ACS, and even the very best specialists can make mistakes, as was evident in my situation.
What Is Acute Chest Syndrome?
Acute chest syndrome is a serious lung condition that can cause symptoms like fever, cough, trouble breathing, and chest pain. It happens when sickled cells get stuck together in the lungs.

How Do I Know What to Watch for With ACS?

Looking back now, there is definitely one thing I would do differently. I would not accept that they send her home. I would insist that they observe her for at least 24 to 48 hours because ACS develops very quickly. So even if an X-ray looks good now, the condition deteriorates very rapidly. Request a repeat X-ray so you can see how it’s progressing.
bullets: Lung infection, like pneumonia. This is when the lungs get infected, which can make breathing difficult.
Pain crisis called vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC). Severe pain that can happen before, during, or after the episode, even if the patient is already in the hospital.
A blood vessel blockage. Sometimes ACS is caused by a blood vessel blockage in the lungs.
Pain in arms, legs, and back

content: In our case, it was necessary to admit my daughter to the PICU.

Learn About ACS
Every warrior and caregiver should educate themselves about ACS. Because every second counts.
If you care for someone with sickle cell disease (SCD) or if you have SCD, it's crucial to learn about ACS, as it is one of the leading causes of mortality in people with SCD.

bullets: Antibiotics to treat a possible lung infection, like pneumonia
Oxygen, if the blood oxygen level is low
Exchange transfusion. Very important. The goal was to bring her HbSS to less than 20% so that her lungs receive healthy red blood cells and thus recover better.
Restart hydroxyurea (to increase her HbF level)
